CatDescriptText: Eugene Holland, postal employee, Homewood and Ernestine Zellars, seamstress, Hazelwood, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the names of juveniles who commit felonies, as distinguished from misdemeanors, should be published in the newspapers?"  Eugene Holland's answer reads: "Sure, if they commit a grown-up crime, they should receive grown-up punishment."  Ernestine Zellars' answer reads: "I don't think so, because many times a juvenile commits one crime and he does not commit another crime in his lifetime.  Of course, if the crime he commits is murder, or some other real serious crime, I think his name should be published."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Eugene Holland wearing dark cap, eyeglasses, moustache, dark scarf, and striped coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Ernestine Zellars wearing light colored hat, tweed coat, and knit gloves, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
